noise deronda awaiting barge now turning head to river side saw at few yard distant from figure might have be impersonation of misery be unconsciously giving voice to girl hardly more than eighteen of low slim figure with most delicate little face dark curl pushed behind ear under large black hat long woolen cloak over shoulder hand be hanging down clasped before eye be fixed on river with look of immovable statue like despair strong arrest of attention made cease singing apparently voice have entered inner world without taking note of whence came for when suddenly ceased changed attitude slightly looking round with frightened glance met derondas face be couple of moment seemed long while for two people to look straight at other look be something like of fawn other gentle animal before because what have said be like long unhappy future unrolled before did not want to be artist be what father expected of after while signora left governess used to come give lesson in different thing felt must be wrong to leave father dreaded doing wrong for thought might get wicked hateful to myself in same way that many others seemed hateful to for so long so long have never felt outside world happy if got wicked must lose world of happy thought where mother lived with be childish notion through year oh how long be mirah fell to musing again have no teaching about what be duty said mr meyrick did not like to say religionfinding on inspection rather dim a to what hebrew religion might have turned into at date noonly ought to do what father wished did not follow religion at new york think wanted not to know much about because mother used to take to synagogue remembered sitting on knee looking through railing hearing chanting singing longed to go one day when be quite small slipped out tried to find synagogue lost long while till peddler questioned took home father missing have be much in fear be very angry too have be so frightened at losing that be long before thought of venturing out again after signora left went to room where landlady be jewess observed religion asked to take with to synagogue read in prayer book bible when have money enough asked to buy book of own for book seemed closer companionship with mother knew that must have looked at very word said in way have come to know little of religion history of people besides piecing together what read in play other book about jew jewess because be sure mother obeyed religion have left off asking father about be very dreadful to say began to disbelieve have found that did not always tell truth made promise without meaning to keep that raised suspicion that mother brother be still alive though have told be dead for in going over past again a got older knew more felt sure that mother have be deceived have expected to see back again after very little while father taking on knee telling that mother brother be dead seemed to now bit of acting to set mind at rest cruelty of falsehood sank into hated untruth because of wrote to mother secretly knew street colman street where lived that be not blackfriar bridge coburg that name be cohen then though father called because said be name of among different sort of people knew german quite wellsome german play almost by heart father spoke better than spoke english be thirteen then seemed to myself quite oldi knew so much yet so little think other child can not feel a did have often wished that have be drowned when be going away from mother set to obey suffer what else must do one day when be on voyage new thought came into mind be not very ill that time kept on deck good deal father acted sang joked to amuse people on board used often to hear remark about one day when be looking at sea nobody took notice of overheard gentleman say oh be one of clever jewsa rascal shouldnt wonder there race like for cunning in men beauty in woman wonder what market mean that daughter for when heard darted into mind that unhappiness in life came from being jewess always to end world must think slightly of must bear for must be judged by name comforted to believe that suffering be part of affliction of people part in long song of mourning have be going on through age age for if many of race be wicked made merry in wickednesswhat be that part of affliction borne by just among who be despised for sin of brethrenbut have not rejected mirah have changed tone in last sentence having suddenly reflected at moment have reason not for complaint for gratitude will try to save from being judged unjustly by others poor child said mr meyrick who have now given up attempt at going on with work sat listening with folded hand face hardly le eager than mabs must have be go on go on tell after lived in different townshamburg vienna longest began to study singing again father always got money about theatre think brought good deal of money from america never knew why left for time be in great spirit about singing made rehearse publicit be gold thread of gold dust father be bitterly disappointed be not so well off at time think have not quite told what felt about father knew be fond of meant to indulge that made afraid of jewess actress when came to next day in theatre must put shawl around terror took hold of saw that father wanted to look pleased count be very young very old hair eye be pale be tall walked heavily must rather stay on stage forever left there hurrying out of room saw father sauntering in passage heart be crushed went past locked up have sunk into that father be in conspiracy with man against next day persuaded to come out said that have mistaken everything must explain if did not come out act fulfill engagement must be ruined must starve so went on acting for week more count never came future not put nonsensical feeling between fortune said what will do will be brought down to sing beg at people door have have splendid offer ought to accept must not speak horror took possession of attention mirah hesitated before said be too ready to speak of trouble think seems unkind to put anything painful into other people mind unless one be sure must hinder something worse perhaps be too lady said wanted to give daughter lesson then never heard of again perhaps after holiday will teach in school besides know be a rich a princess now have not touched hundred pound mr klesmer gave must
